This work was financially supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China under Grant No. 41771457, No. 51674042. The associate editor coordinating the review of this article and approving it for publication was Dr. Zhihan Lv. (Corresponding authors: Sheng He; Yiting Tao.) J. Liu, S. He, and Y. Tao are with the State Key Laboratory of Information Engineering in Surveying, Mapping and Remote Sensing, Wuhan University, Wuhan 430072, China (e-mail: jliu@sgg.whu.edu.cn; whusheng1996@163.com; taoyiting516@126.com).

head.citation-title: Realtime RGB-Based 3D Object Pose Detection Using Convolutional Neural Networks
head.abstracts: © 2001-2012 IEEE.We present a new approach to efficiently detect the 3D pose of objects in images. The approach uses a single neural network we call TQ-Net to predict the translation vector and the quaternion, after which the quaternion is converted to a rotation matrix, and through a projection algorithm, we can project eight points surrounding the object to the image and connect them to form a 3D bounding box. Considering there is a constraint existing in the quaternion, we add a normalization layer to get a more precise result. Experiments show that our approach performs well and can detect 3D poses in real time. Our approach processes images with a resolution of 1280∗720 at 61 frames per second on a GTX 1080 GPU.

coredata.dc:description: We present a new approach to efficiently detect the 3D pose of objects in images. The approach uses a single neural network we call TQ-Net to predict the translation vector and the quaternion, after which the quaternion is converted to a rotation matrix, and through a projection algorithm, we can project eight points surrounding the object to the image and connect them to form a 3D bounding box. Considering there is a constraint existing in the quaternion, we add a normalization layer to get a more precise result. Experiments show that our approach performs well and can detect 3D poses in real time. Our approach processes images with a resolution of 1280∗720 at 61 frames per second on a GTX 1080 GPU.
coredata.dc:title: Realtime RGB-Based 3D Object Pose Detection Using Convolutional Neural Networks
coredata.dc:publisher: Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers Inc.
